item.title: 317 Packet Ids
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“thiefmn6092, post:10, topic:534817”][quote author=AtomicInt_ link=topic=653615.msg4379505#msg4379505 date=1383091089]

That array is reshuffled on significant engine updates correct? Making it harder to emulate, due to all the opcodes changing.

[10/28/2013 7:02:48 PM] Hadyn: These ids, dont change revision to revision
[10/28/2013 7:03:03 PM] Hadyn: Which changes the whole structure of RSPS was supposed to be made
[10/28/2013 7:03:12 PM] Hadyn: Graham did it wrong, made is super complex IMO
[/quote]

ffs graham always coding code wrong

i guess u should stop using all of his code then rofl[/quote]

its the best of the worst of what there is to offer.

Read full topic

No, the array gets shuffled. But these packet ids dont change revision to revision.

for how many revisions can you confirm that this is correct?

Up to 400. Beyond that, the array doesn’t exist in the client anymore :
[/quote]
Damn. That array would be very useful for newer revisions. :P[/quote]

And old! Too bad this is just now being found out.

item.title: 317 Packet Ids
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

If you are familiar with client hacking, specifically hacking the 317 build of the client, you may have seen this array:

final class SizeConstants {

    public static final int[] anIntArray552 = {
        6, 21, 25, 33, 254, 127, 183, 87, 216, 215, 
        211, 48, 15, 195, 149, 233, 162, 102, 104, 179, 
        222, 103, 224, 81, 152, 89, 45, 11, 197, 187, 
        210, 37, 135, 220, 137, 128, 63, 188, 207, 144, 
        201, 161, 28, 192, 206, 32, 115, 57, 196, 22, 
        132, 226, 227, 169, 237, 105, 174, 109, 5, 55, 
        205, 156, 8, 34, 113, 176, 209, 3, 50, 117, 
        122, 189, 101, 142, 246, 163, 238, 76, 74, 84, 
        91, 217, 58, 23, 118, 66, 35, 164, 114, 138, 
        96, 110, 29, 235, 147, 249, 214, 198, 242, 56, 
        94, 248, 59, 253, 150, 16, 13, 46, 24, 130, 
        232, 153, 167, 229, 79, 134, 26, 191, 0, 213, 
        204, 241, 160, 39, 180, 49, 250, 47, 140, 193, 
        202, 108, 120, 247, 106, 194, 65, 27, 93, 143, 
        186, 171, 125, 54, 155, 190, 139, 165, 77, 178, 
        72, 99, 61, 141, 116, 100, 80, 184, 154, 145, 
        131, 12, 90, 42, 255, 75, 44, 78, 172, 107, 
        52, 7, 119, 146, 38, 218, 10, 223, 182, 240, 
        159, 88, 158, 64, 221, 200, 1, 43, 252, 62, 
        40, 230, 129, 18, 111, 51, 17, 53, 136, 20, 
        60, 225, 30, 9, 239, 97, 234, 41, 203, 236, 
        36, 185, 212, 19, 245, 251, 208, 175, 243, 86, 
        2, 69, 181, 151, 14, 166, 70, 98, 124, 126, 
        67, 157, 199, 112, 123, 177, 82, 168, 71, 170, 
        95, 31, 92, 4, 231, 219, 73, 85, 244, 148, 
        173, 228, 121, 83, 133, 68, 0
    };

What properties does this array have?

There isn’t a single number in the array that repeats, the array length is 257, the range of the values in the array is from 0 to 255 inclusive.

So, this means?

Just based from that information and the location of where the array is that this data maps the obfuscated id of a packet to the actual id of a packet.

tl;dr What is it?

It’s an array that maps the obfuscated packet ids to actual ids.

Here’s a print out of the actual packet ids and a tag for functionality:

idle, 6
logout, 30
click, 31
anticheat, 32
focus_change, 33
camera_rotated, 35
check_9, 60
check_8, 61
check_7, 62
check_10, 63
check_6, 65
check_4, 71
check_5, 72
check_0, 73
check_2, 74
check_1, 76
check_3, 77
gitem_option_1, 80
npc_option_1, 100
obj_option_1, 120
plr_option_1, 140
plr_option_2, 141
item_option_1, 160
item_on_item, 169
container_option_1, 190
close_interfaces, 202
num_input, 203
tab_changed, 204
text_input, 205
item_on_plr, 216
map_rebuilt, 241
interaction_route, 242
report, 243
minimap_route, 244
item_swapped, 245
rm_ignore, 246
add_ignore, 247
appearance, 248
chat_filters, 249
priv_msg, 250
rm_friend, 251
add_friend, 252
cmd, 253
chat, 254
tile_route, 255

List of used packets

"[[6, \"used\"], [30, \"used\"], [31, \"used\"], [32, \"used\"], [33, \"used\"], [35, \"used\"], [36, \"used\"], [60, \"used\"], [61, \"used\"], [62, \"used\"], [63, \"used\"], [64, \"used\"], [65, \"used\"], [66, \"used\"], [67, \"used\"], [70, \"used\"], [71, \"used\"], [72, \"used\"], [73, \"used\"], [74, \"used\"], [75, \"used\"], [76, \"used\"], [77, \"used\"], [80, \"used\"], [81, \"used\"], [82, \"used\"], [83, \"used\"], [84, \"used\"], [88, \"used\"], [89, \"used\"], [100, \"used\"], [101, \"used\"], [102, \"used\"], [103, \"used\"], [104, \"used\"], [108, \"used\"], [109, \"used\"], [120, \"used\"], [121, \"used\"], [122, \"used\"], [123, \"used\"], [124, \"used\"], [128, \"used\"], [129, \"used\"], [140, \"used\"], [141, \"used\"], [142, \"used\"], [143, \"used\"], [144, \"used\"], [148, \"used\"], [149, \"used\"], [160, \"used\"], [161, \"used\"], [162, \"used\"], [163, \"used\"], [164, \"used\"], [168, \"used\"], [169, \"used\"], [190, \"used\"], [191, \"used\"], [192, \"used\"], [193, \"used\"], [194, \"used\"], [200, \"used\"], [201, \"used\"], [202, \"used\"], [203, \"used\"], [204, \"used\"], [205, \"used\"], [241, \"used\"], [242, \"used\"], [243, \"used\"], [244, \"used\"], [245, \"used\"], [246, \"used\"], [247, \"used\"], [248, \"used\"], [249, \"used\"], [250, \"used\"], [251, \"used\"], [252, \"used\"], [253, \"used\"], [254, \"used\"], [255, \"used\"]]"
